24.44.text: First in the spotlight tonight is the actress Lisa Maxwell.

33.12.text: The comedian Gary Delaney answers questions on

36.08.text: the zombie films of George Romero.

40.52.text: Next, the actor Simon Greenall on the D-Day landings.

48.00.text: And the BBC commentator Conor McNamara on Irish whiskey.

60.84.text: Hello and welcome to Celebrity Mastermind with me,

64.40.text: John Humphrys, and four people who have achieved a lot over the years.

69.48.text: And now, well, they could be putting it all at risk depending on how

73.04.text: they equip themselves in that black chair.

75.24.text: But they are doing it all for charity.

78.28.text: The rules are the same - 90 seconds of questions on their

80.96.text: specialist subject and then two minutes on general knowledge.

84.28.text: So let us ask our first contender to join us please.

103.72.text: Garland was born Frances Ethel Gumm in June 1922,

106.52.text: the youngest of three sisters. By what nickname was

109.28.text: she known early in her professional career?

- Judgment At Nuremberg.

220.88.text: The name of that venue in Copenhagen was the Falkoner Centre.

303.40.text: the zombies on an island off the coast of Delaware,

644.80.text: Joint first place, 10 points a piece, Gary and Simon.

668.08.text: Lisa, you are about, I think, aren't you,

671.52.text:
- to start playing the lady herself? 
- Yes. 
- I mean, for heaven's sake!

677.32.text: Judy Garland. How scary is that?

679.60.text: It's terrifying. It's a play called End Of The Rainbow.

683.28.text: So I'm playing her in the last two weeks of her life.

688.40.text: So I need to go home and actually read a bit more about her.

691.60.text: And she was, it's an overused word, but she was - or is - a legend.

695.96.text: She is a proper bona fide legend. I think it was her vulnerability.

699.72.text: I think she wore her heart on her sleeve and when you see her perform,

703.36.text: you can see that she is actually giving you absolutely everything.

707.40.text:
- Which, you know, is no pressure. 
- Exactly.

711.64.text: She paid a price for it, didn't she?

713.36.text: She did. I mean, she was taking pep pills from the age of 12,

717.48.text:
- given to her by her mother. 
- The age of 12?! 
- Age 12.

720.08.text: So that she could do the late nights in the theatre.

722.56.text: And then diet pills and so on.

725.12.text: I think, from everything I've read, she was only truly happy when

728.00.text: she was in front of an audience, which is kind of sad really.

730.84.text:
- Isn't it? Well, good luck with the role. 
- Thank you, John.

733.96.text: Should be brilliant. Here we go now with your general knowledge.

914.16.text:
- Jack of all trades.

916.64.text:
- Master of none.

921.00.text: What I do find challenging is in golf, you've got to whisper.

928.56.text: But in golf, you are beside the green.

936.76.text: a little bit too close to the green.

938.40.text: He's describing the putt and goes, "It's 14ft, it's downhill,

945.80.text: And the golfer turns round and he says, "Oy, you. Shut it!

948.48.text: "And by the way, it was right to left, not left to right."

953.52.text: I thought perhaps you would have said rugby

955.80.text: because the rules are now so complicated.

959.44.text: even the people who play it don't fully understand the rules.

962.28.text:
- That's true. 
- Absolutely, it's a very complicated game.

965.40.text: I actually think, though, it's an attraction of rugby, particularly

968.48.text: watching it on television, is the discussion you have.

971.00.text: Why was that a penalty? Let's discuss it.

972.96.text: It's not always straightforward. But that's actually part of what

975.84.text: draws people into the game, to understand it.

1145.76.text: Can anybody tell a joke or is it true that it's the way you tell 'em?

1150.28.text: Honestly, I think timing is a little bit of a myth.

1155.24.text: People talk it up as being the epitome of everything.

1157.76.text: I think the secret to timing is actually relatively simple.

1160.44.text: You don't speak too fast, you do a little pause before the funny bit.

1163.40.text: I don't think that's a great difficulty. The main thing about

1166.24.text: being a comedian is just having the nerve to get up there and do it.

1169.12.text:
- If you can get through that...

1171.56.text: Yeah, I genuinely think it is.

1172.88.text: I think it's just... Just to make you practice.

1175.32.text: As long as you can get up there then you can bang

1177.68.text:
- out some gags.

1181.04.text: I don't know, Ken Dodd or Eric Morecambe or somebody.

1184.16.text: You know, you would assume that they've got that particular gift

1187.24.text: of just being able to stand there and make people laugh.

1191.08.text: Lots of people are funny but you have to learn how to do

1425.12.text: and an actor who can do voices the way you can do them?

1430.20.text:
- You mean they get more than you?

1432.16.text: No, come on. What's the difference?

1433.72.text: I don't really know the difference. It's a different...

1436.56.text: It's to do with your ears. It's to do with hearing.

1439.56.text: Impressionists are kind of a blank canvas and they can take people on.

1443.72.text: Whereas doing character voices, you kind of invent the character

1447.28.text: and then build the voice onto it.

1449.40.text: So it's a different process. It's a slight tic in the brain.

1569.60.text: The 2015 film Legend tells the story of which pair of twins,

1574.08.text: who became two of the most notorious gangsters in British history?

1578.60.text: The head of which animal was often served with an apple or

1581.36.text: orange in its mouth at Olde English Christmas banquets?

1585.16.text: Or boar. Which 1951 JD Salinger novel begins with the line,

1588.60.text: "If you really want to hear about it, the first thing you'll probably

1591.92.text: "want to know is where I was born and what my lousy childhood was like."

1596.48.text: Who sang with Queen on their 1981 UK number one hit Under Pressure?

1601.44.text: In which Sheffield theatre is the World Professional Snooker Championship held?

1609.44.text: ..particularly associated with desert areas has a pair of grasping pincers

1613.04.text: and a segmented curved tail ending in a sting?

1616.60.text: Is correct. You had two passes.

1618.40.text: David Bowie sang with Queen on Under Pressure.

1621.64.text: And that very small mammal is very closely related to the elephant.

1628.96.text: You've scored a total, Simon, of 24 points.

1641.80.text: Well, a clear winner there. Let's have a look at the scores.

1672.88.text: Tell me, what would a meerkat have said if it had won the prize?

1676.60.text: Not simples, because it wasn't simples.

1684.04.text: Well done. You don't have to be a celebrity, of course,

1686.40.text: to take part in the regular Mastermind programme.

1688.68.text: So, if you would like to appear in the next series on BBC Two

1692.32.text: then do visit us online at...

1696.24.text: Or you can follow us on Twitter at...

1699.68.text: Either way, do join us again next time for more Mastermind.
